speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tries to wake Juliet, calling her various affectionate names and scolding her for sleeping in. She jokes that Juliet should sleep now because Paris will keep her awake on their wedding night. She then grows concerned at Juliet's lack of response, decides she must wake her, and finally realizes Juliet appears dead, crying out in distress and calling for aqua vitae (a strong liquor) and the Capulets.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet enters and asks what the commotion is about.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse exclaims that it is a sorrowful day.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks what has happened.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells her to look and calls it a grievous day.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Seeing Juliet, she cries out in anguish, calling Juliet her only life and begging her to revive or else she will die too, then calls for help.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet enters, impatiently telling them to bring Juliet out because Paris has arrived.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells him Juliet is dead, alas.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet echoes the Nurse, lamenting repeatedly that Juliet is dead.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He examines Juliet and finds her cold, with still blood and stiff joints, confirming she has been dead for some time. He compares Death to a frost that has killed the sweetest flower in the field.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse again cries what a lamentable day it is.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet calls it a woeful time.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He says Death has taken Juliet to make him grieve, and now it has stolen his ability to speak.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar arrives with Paris and asks if the bride is ready to go to church.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He answers bitterly that she is ready to go but not to return. He tells Paris that Death has slept with his bride, deflowering her, and that Death is now his son-in-law and heir to all he owns.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris says he has long looked forward to this wedding morning, and now it shows him this terrible sight instead.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She curses this day as wretched and hateful, calling it the most miserable hour ever witnessed in time's long journey. She had only one beloved child to bring her joy and comfort, but cruel death has taken that child away.

speaker: NURSE
content: She exclaims repeatedly about the woeful and lamentable day, declaring it the darkest day she has ever seen. Her repetition emphasizes overwhelming grief.

speaker: PARIS
content: He feels deceived, wronged, and slain by death, calling death detestable and cruel. He laments not life itself, but love that persists even in death.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He describes Juliet as despised, distressed, and killed, asking why this uncomfortable (distressing) time had to ruin their celebration. He declares his child dead and with her, all his joys are buried.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He tells them to be quiet and ashamed, saying that disorder cannot be cured by more disorder. He argues that heaven now has Juliet entirely, which is better for her since she lives eternally. He chides them for weeping when she is exalted in heaven, saying they love her poorly by mourning when she is well off. He states that a long marriage is not the best; dying young after marriage is better. He tells them to dry tears, place rosemary (a funeral herb) on her body, dress her well, and take her to church, explaining that while natural grief makes us cry, reason should bring joy.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He observes that everything planned for celebration has turned to funeral use: instruments become funeral bells, wedding feast becomes burial meal, hymns become sad songs, and bridal flowers adorn a corpse.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He instructs Capulet, Lady Capulet, and Paris to go prepare to follow Juliet’s body to the grave. He warns that the heavens frown on them for some wrong, and they should not oppose heaven’s will further.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He remarks that they can pack up their instruments and leave.

speaker: NURSE
content: She tells the musicians to put away their instruments, acknowledging this is a pitiful situation.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He replies, 'by my troth' (truly), the situation could be improved — a pun on 'case' as both situation and instrument case.

speaker: PETER
content: He calls for the musicians to play 'Heart’s ease,' a popular tune, saying if they want him to live they should play it.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He asks why 'Heart’s ease'?

speaker: PETER
content: He explains that his heart plays 'My heart is full' (of sorrow), so he wants a merry dump (a slow, sad dance tune) to comfort him.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He refuses, saying it’s not the time to play now.

speaker: PETER
content: He asks if they really won’t play.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He simply says no.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter threatens to beat the musicians soundly, meaning thoroughly or severely.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician misunderstands and asks what Peter will give them, expecting a payment.

speaker: PETER
content: He says he will give them no money but a gleek, meaning a jest or taunt, and calls them minstrels insultingly.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician retorts by calling Peter a serving-creature, a demeaning term for a servant.

speaker: PETER
content: He threatens to hit the musician's head with a dagger and says he will carry no crotchets, meaning both quarter notes in music and whims or complaints. He then puns on musical notes re and fa, meaning he will attack them.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician plays on Peter's words, saying if you re and fa us, you note us, meaning both musical notes and observe/attack us.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: He asks Peter to put away his dagger and show his wit instead, using put out to mean display.

speaker: PETER
content: He says he will attack with his wit, dry-beat meaning thrash without drawing blood, and put up his dagger. He then quotes a poem about music soothing grief and questions why it says silver sound, challenging each musician in turn.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He answers that silver has a sweet sound, taking the phrase literally.

speaker: PETER
content: He dismisses this as prates, meaning idle chatter.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: He offers a pun that musicians sound for silver, meaning they play for money.

speaker: PETER
content: He rejects this answer too as prates.

speaker: THIRD MUSICIAN
content: He admits he does not know what to say.

speaker: PETER
content: He sarcastically says he will answer for the musician: music has a silver sound because musicians are paid in silver, not gold. He finishes the verse and exits. This mocks the musicians' poverty.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He calls Peter a pestilent knave, meaning a troublesome rogue.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: He suggests they ignore Peter, go inside, wait for the mourners, and stay for dinner.
